newsitem.title: DUBAI: Iran to replace old tanker fleet, buys from Daewoo.
newsitem.headline: Iran to replace old tanker fleet, buys from Daewoo.

text.p: Iran's state-owned National Iranian Tanker Company (NITC) is moving quickly to buy new oil tankers to replace its ageing fleet, Iranian and Gulf shipping sources said on Tuesday.

NITC has awarded a contract to South Korea's Daewoo Heavy Industries Co for five 158,000-tonne Suezmax type oil tankers and will award a contract for five more 100,000-tonne Aframax tankers in the next two months, they said.
"The first Suezmax cargo will arrive within 27 months and each of the other four will be delivered every 45 days after that," NITC chairman Mohammad Souri told Reuters.
A contract for Aframax tankers -- which will be mainly used to supply Iranian crude to the country's new refinery at Bandar Abbas -- was planned to be awarded within two months, he added.
NITC aims to buy five oil product carriers and five Very Large Crude Carriers (VLCC) after the Aframax purchases.
A Daewoo spokesman in Seoul on Tuesday said its Suezmax contract, which will take oil produced by the National Iranian Oil Co (NIOC) to Mediterranean markets, was worth $300 million.
Souri estimated that each of the Aframax cargoes would be worth around $40 million.

NITC has secured new tankers to replace its fleet much of which pre-dated the country's 1979 Islamic revolution. NITC has scrapped 15 of its tankers in recent years, reducing its own fleet to 11 crude tankers and nine product tankers.

This has frequently forced NITC to spend scarce hard currency to time-charter vessels from the international spot market to transport oil to Iran's main export markets in Asia, Europe and the Americas, shipping sources said.
"Their fleet was simply rusting or becoming dangerous...They suffered from breakdowns and high costs so the time came when they simply had to buy new," said a Gulf shipping source.

NITC, a wholly owned subsidiary of NIOC, is responsible for exporting some 950,000 barrels per day (bpd) of Iran's 2.6 million bpd crude exports on a "delivered" or charge, insurance and freight (cif) basis.
It also time charters its own VLCCs in the spot market.
Iran is the world's third largest oil exporter behind Saudi Arabia and Norway and is heavily reliant on the $18 billion a year that oil revenues brings to the country.
Daewoo supplied NITC with five 300,000-tonne VLCCs in 1996.
